channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: A Cash Chokehold on North Korea Gets Tighter
item.description: North Korea finds itself losing critical support as the sources of foreign currency that maintain its military ambitions show signs of drying up.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, center, visited a construction site of the North Korean army on Tuesday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 8
item.description: The U.S. considers Internet surveillance; harsh tactics in Nigeria; a Brazilian will lead the W.T.O.; and Aboriginal artwork goes back to Australia.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: The hospital morgue in Maiduguri, Nigeria, where large numbers of bodies have been brought.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Asian Development Bank’s Chief Economist Changyong Rhee
item.description: Mr. Rhee on how India could improve upon delivery of public services and reduce poverty.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Ireland Pardons Wartime Deserter ‘Heroes’
item.description: Almost 70 years after the end of World War II, Ireland is granting amnesty to soldiers who were punished for deserting their units to join the British war effort against the Nazis.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Britain's Queen Elizabeth laid a wreath at Dublin's Irish National War Memorial on May 18, 2011.

item.title: State Dept. Official to Testify on Benghazi Attacks
item.description: Congressional Republicans say their hearing, featuring a witness from the State Department, will yield a damning indictment of the Obama administration’s response to the attacks in Libya.
item.category: House Oversight and Government Reform Committee
item.dc:creator: By JEREMY W. PETERS and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Disease Is Ravaging Continent’s Staple
item.description: Scientists say a disease destroying entire crops of cassava has spread out of East Africa into the heart of the continent, is attacking plants as far south as Angola and threatens to move west into Nigeria.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: F.B.I. Director in Moscow to Discuss Boston Bombings
item.description: The F.B.I. director Robert S. Mueller III met with Russian officials in Moscow on Tuesday to discuss the the Boston bombings, according to American officials.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: U.S. Penalizes Drug Traffickers
item.description: The Treasury Department announced sanctions against eight Mexicans on Tuesday whom it identified as the main bosses for the Sinaloa Cartel.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Obama Backs Policy of South Korea’s Park on North
item.description: President Obama endorsed President Park Geun-hye’s plans for defusing tensions with North Korea, but warned that the first move was up to Kim Jong-un.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: President Obama met President Park Geun-hye, South Korea’s first female leader, for the first time Tuesday in the Oval Office.

item.title: Hezbollah Takes Risks by Fighting Rebels in Syria
item.description: Trained to battle Israel, Hezbollah’s Lebanese Shiite guerrillas are pushing into a very different fight, against fellow Arab Muslims trying to topple President Bashar al-Assad.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard of the Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah and President Bashar al-Assad in Baalbak, Lebanon. Hezbollah has supported Mr. Assad in the Syrian war.

item.title: New Head of C.I.A.’s Clandestine Service Is Chosen
item.description: The choice of a candidate without direct ties to a controversial detention and interrogation program may signal the new C.I.A. director’s aim to distance himself from it.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Death Toll in Collapse of Garment Factories Passes 700
item.description: The death toll from the collapse last month of a building housing garment factories reached 705 on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Government to Pardon Soldiers Who Fought for Britain in World War II
item.description: The government said Tuesday that it was pardoning nearly 5,000 men who deserted Ireland’s armed forces to fight for Britain during World War II.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Gas Tanker Explodes; 22 Dead
item.description: A double tanker transporting gas struck a containment wall on a highway in a Mexico City suburb on Tuesday and burst into flames, killing 22 people and injuring 31.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY

item.title: Sunnis in Iraq Protest Antiterror Tactics That Hurt Innocents
item.description: United States-imposed laws are central to the protest movement, as those who once helped the American military now sometimes put innocent people in prison in their work as informants for the Iraqi government.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Sunnis protesting against the government last week in Falluja, Iraq. At the core of grievances are United States-imposed laws.

item.title: China Criticizes Pentagon Report on Cyberattacks
item.description: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs criticized a Pentagon report that accused China’s military of cyberattacks on the American government and military contractors.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: U.S. Accuses China’s Military in Cyberattacks
item.description: The Pentagon explicitly accused China of attacking government systems and defense contractors, possibly to map “military capabilities that could be exploited during a crisis.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Highest Rate of First-Day Deaths of Newborns in Africa
item.description: Fourteen countries in Africa have the highest rates, while India has the highest number of such deaths, according to the report by the aid group Save the Children.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Israel Halts Settlement Plans for Now, Group Says
item.description: A leftist group said the move by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was apparently intended to give Secretary of State John Kerry more time to restart peace talks.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Body Count Soars as Nigerian Military Hunts Islamists
item.description: The military’s harsh tactics have curtailed militant attacks in the north, a stronghold of Boko Haram, but at a huge cost and with likely repercussions.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: The hospital morgue in Maiduguri, Nigeria, where large numbers of bodies are brought.

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,201 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: South Korea’s President Visits the U.S.
item.description: As President Park Geun-hye makes her first visit to Washington, South Koreans discuss the importance of their country’s relationship with the United States in light of the conflict with North Korea.

item.title: Russia and U.S. to Convene Peace Conference on Syria
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry and Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia jointly intensified pressure on Syria to settle a conflict that has killed more than 70,000.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry and Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov in the garden of the Foreign Ministry in Moscow on Tuesday. They agreed to peace talks on Syria after a day of meetings.

item.title: Spanish Court Drops Subpoena Against Princess Cristina
item.description: Princess Cristina will not have to appear in court in an embezzlement case in which her husband is under investigation.
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Morsi Reshuffles Egyptian Cabinet
item.description: President Mohamed Morsi’s shake-up increased the role of Islamists in the government’s upper ranks but was not expected to lead to new policies.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and MAYY EL SHEIKH
